===Economic downturn and resurgence=== Sales of high-rise condominiums began to decrease in 2008.<ref name=GrowSlow>{{cite news|last=Robison|first=Jennifer|title=As high-rises grow, sales slow|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/high-rises-grow-sales-slow|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 3, 2008}}</ref> The condo-hotel market, consisting of projects on and near the Las Vegas Strip, also suffered that year because of low sales; thousands of condo-hotel units had been cancelled up to that point.<ref>{{cite news|last=Benston|first=Liz|title=Strip's vaunted condo-hotels losing their luster: High fees, slowed rental demand dampen market|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/may/20/strips-vaunted-condo-hotels-losing-their-luster/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=May 20, 2008}}</ref> By the end of 2008, only three additional developers had successfully completed condominium high-rises near the Las Vegas Strip: [[MGM Resorts International|MGM Mirage]] (The Signature), [[Donald Trump]] ([[#Trump International|Trump International]]), and Andrew Fonfa ([[#Allure Las Vegas|Allure Las Vegas]]).<ref>{{cite news|last=Friess|first=Steve|title=Flower Tower|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/oct/02/flower-tower/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=October 2, 2008}}</ref> In 2009, condominium and condo-hotel units on and near the Las Vegas Strip were still struggling to sell because of the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Benston|first=Liz|title=The Harmon isn't Strip's only troubled condo|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/jan/12/harmon-isnt-strips-only-troubled-condo/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=January 12, 2009}}</ref>
As of August 2009, less than 25 percent of the proposed condominium projects had been built, as predicted by some analysts; developers of projects that were completed were having difficulty selling their units as a result of the [[Great Recession in the United States|2008 recession]].<ref name=FallFlat>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/high-rise-plans-go-flat-las-vegas|title= High-rise plans go flat in Las Vegas|last= Smith|first= Hubble|date= August 2, 2009|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> Sales of high-rise condominiums increased seven percent in the third quarter of 2009, although condo-hotels continued to struggle.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wargo|first=Buck|title=Las Vegas condo hotels remain a tough sell — just ask Trump|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/nov/20/las-vegas-condo-hotels-remain-tough-sell-just-ask-/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=November 20, 2009}}</ref> Poor condominium sales continued into the following year.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/problems-continue-high-rise-condo-market|title= Problems continue in high-rise condo market|last= Smith|first= Hubble|date= May 28, 2010|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> In June 2010, there were 5,500 high-rise condominium units and 5,400 condo-hotel units in the Las Vegas Valley.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wargo|first=Buck|title=Capping a 'Decade of Extremes': From building boom to recessionary bust, local real estate market was a wild ride that went south |url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2010/jun/11/building-boom-recessionary-bust-local-real-estate-/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 11, 2010}}</ref> By that point, developers of several high-rise condominium properties had begun renting their vacant units, which were left unsold because of the poor economy.<ref name=LVS-Jun18-2010>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2010/jun/18/renting-new-savior-high-rise-condos/|title= Renting is new savior for high-rise condos|last= Wargo|first= Buck|date= June 18, 2010|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
Sales of high-rise condominiums had increased in 2011, with many units being sold at a reduced cost through bank sales, short sales, and foreclosures to investors, who would subsequently improve and [[flipping|flip]] the units. The largest increase occurred at properties on and near the Las Vegas Strip. However, sales of new condominiums were down, and the condo-hotel market also continued to suffer.<ref name=Ramping>{{cite news|last=Wargo|first=Buck|title=Investors ramping up Las Vegas condo sales|url=https://www.vegasinc.com/business/tourism/2011/aug/10/investors-ramping-las-vegas-condo-sales/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=August 10, 2011}}</ref> High-rise sales were expected to increase in 2015 as the market continued to recover.<ref>{{cite news|last=Devore|first=Holly Ivy|title=Experts expect high-rise sales to be up in 2015|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/real-estate-millions/experts-expect-high-rise-sales-be-2015|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 11, 2015}}</ref>
By 2016, the construction industry in Las Vegas had been revived, although there were no plans for any new high-rise condominium projects.<ref name=Vegas2016>{{cite news|last=Segall|first=Eli|title=Why are high-rises missing from the construction rebound in Las Vegas?|url=https://vegasinc.com/news/2016/jun/27/why-are-high-rises-missing-from-the-construction-r/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=VegasInc.com|date=June 27, 2016}}</ref> Prices for existing high-rise condominiums had increased by that time. Demand for high-rise homes on the Las Vegas Strip was projected to increase because of the opening of the [[T-Mobile Arena]], as well as the announcement of an [[National Hockey League|NHL]] expansion franchise and discussions about a potential [[National Football League|NFL]] team in Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite news|last=Devore|first=Holly Ivy|title=High-rise market heats up|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/real-estate-millions/high-rise-market-heats|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 18, 2016}}</ref>
==Completed projects== ===Allure Las Vegas=== {{Main article|Allure Las Vegas}}
Allure was announced in January 2005,<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Chicago group planning luxury condominiums for Strip|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-18-Tue-2005/business/25682049.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 18, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050120060625/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-18-Tue-2005/business/25682049.html|archivedate=January 20, 2005}}</ref> and began construction in September 2005.<ref name=Go-up>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Will what goes down go up?|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Nov-06-Sun-2005/business/3832984.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=November 6, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060205090413/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Nov-06-Sun-2005/business/3832984.html|archivedate=February 5, 2006}}</ref> Allure, located west of the Las Vegas Strip, was completed in December 2007, and was the tallest residential building within Las Vegas city limits at that time, standing 41 stories high with a total of 428 units. The tower was built at a cost of $150 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Certificate of occupancy secured for Allure Las Vegas|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/certificate-occupancy-secured-allure-las-vegas|accessdate=February 2, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 7, 2008}}</ref> A second tower was cancelled because of poor sales in the first tower caused by the [[Great Recession in the United States|Great Recession]], and because of an oversupply of condominium high-rises on the Las Vegas Strip.<ref name=LVRJ-2012>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/vacant-lot-may-become-home-asian-themed-resort|title=Vacant lot may become home to Asian-themed resort|last=O'Reiley|first=Tim|date=February 3, 2012|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
===Boca Raton=== Boca Raton consists of two seven-story buildings with a total of 378 units, located at 2405 West Serene Avenue, south of the Las Vegas Strip.<ref name=Boca-2017/><ref>{{cite news |title=Boca Raton News |url=http://www.vegastodayandtomorrow.com/boca_raton.htm |work=VegasTodayAndTomorrow |date=September 12, 2007 |accessdate=August 16, 2018}}</ref> In January 2004, Las Vegas-based Palm Beach Resort Condominiums LLC purchased {{convert|15|acre|abbr=on}} of land at the southwest corner of South Las Vegas Boulevard and Serene Avenue, at a cost of $12.8 million. Unlike approximately 80 other condominium projects, Palm Beach Resort received county approval, had the project designed, and began construction before taking reservations. Stewart Simpson, the senior vice president of development for the project, said at the start of construction, "Most of these projects, they have a concept, they option for a piece of land and go out and start explaining it. Instead of saying we have this dream and hope we can make it happen, we had a dream and we didn't tell anyone about it and did our homework."<ref name=Boca-Nov/> The project was designed by Pierce Goodwin Alexander and Linville (PGAL).<ref name=Boca-Nov/><ref name=Boca-Higher/>
Groundbreaking for the first phase began on November 17, 2004, with completion expected for February 2006. The $400 million project was planned to ultimately consist of four seven-story towers, with a total of 756 units. Prices were expected to start at $200,000. The project was also planned to include a two-story underground parking garage. Las Vegas-based Wright Engineering was the [[project engineer]],<ref name=Boca-Higher/> while UPA Resort Construction Group was the general contractor.<ref name=Boca-Nov>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Hubble |title=Developers put building first: Condominium construction starts ahead of marketing |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041208181733/http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2004/Nov-20-Sat-2004/business/25307553.html |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=November 20, 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041208181733/http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2004/Nov-20-Sat-2004/business/25307553.html |archivedate=December 8, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/nov/17/condo-project-breaks-ground/|title= Condo project breaks ground |date= November 17, 2004|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=August 16, 2018}}</ref> [[JPMorgan Chase]] provided a $134 million [[construction loan]] for the project.<ref name=Boca-2007/> Martin Harris Construction became the general contractor in 2005, and the project's opening was delayed several times because of construction.<ref name=Boca-2007/> By December 2005, the midrise project had sold 270 units in its first two buildings, which contained a total of 378 units. The February 2006 opening had been delayed by that point.<ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |title=Boca Raton takes shape on the South Strip |url=https://nl.newsbank.com |website=Las Vegas Business Press |accessdate=August 16, 2018 |date=November 14, 2005 |subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name=Boca-Higher>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Hubble |title=Boca Raton condos head higher on Strip |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-12-Mon-2005/business/4682020.html |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=December 12, 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051223075345/http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2005/Dec-12-Mon-2005/business/4682020.html |archivedate=December 23, 2005}}</ref> Following the completion of the underground parking garage, upward construction was underway as of January 2006, with the first 172 units scheduled to open in December 2006.<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Hubble |title=Henderson condo project to break ground in March |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2006/Jan-23-Mon-2006/business/5427552.html |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=January 23, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090910171602/http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2006/Jan-23-Mon-2006/business/5427552.html |archivedate=September 10, 2009}}</ref> By May 2006, basketball player [[Paul Pierce]] had purchased a unit in the project.<ref>{{cite news |last=Katsilometes |first=John |title=John Katsilometes has an update on Greg Brady, who's still groovy |url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2006/may/11/john-katsilometes-has-an-update-on-greg-brady-whos/ |work=Las Vegas Sun |date=May 8, 2006 |accessdate=August 16, 2018}}</ref> Both buildings had been topped out by August 2006. The buildings used 16,000 cubic yards of concrete and 2,000 tons of steel, with 250,000 hours spent working on them up to that point. Completion of the first phase was scheduled for January 2007, and would include a {{convert|10000|sqft|abbr=on}} clubhouse.<ref name=Apace/>
Construction was nearing completion in late May 2007, and residents were expected to move in by June.<ref>{{cite news |title=Move-in day coming at Boca Raton condominium project |url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/move-in-day-coming-at-boca-raton-condominium-project/ |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=May 21, 2007 |accessdate=August 16, 2018}}</ref> Approximately 70 people moved in during July 2007, and the 378-unit first phase was entirely finished in October, with 80 percent of the units sold. It was announced that construction for the second phase was 12 to 18 months away.<ref name=Boca-2007>{{cite news |title=Residents moving into Boca Raton condominiums |url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/residents-moving-into-boca-raton-condominiums/ |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=October 22, 2007 |accessdate=August 16, 2018}}</ref> Approximately 160 units were sold in 2007, but sales decreased the following year due to the Great Recession. Unit purchases stopped entirely in 2009, and the other two buildings were cancelled due to the poor economy. JPMorgan Chase sued Boca Raton's developer in 2010, alleging default of the construction loan. In 2011, an investment group purchased Boca Raton. In December 2017, the group listed the remaining 210 unsold units for sale in a bulk offer.<ref name=Boca-2017>{{cite news |last=Segall |first=Eli |title=Investors hope to sell more than 200 condos off Las Vegas Strip |url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/business-columns/real-estate-insider/investors-hope-to-sell-more-than-200-condos-off-las-vegas-strip/ |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=December 8, 2017 |accessdate=August 16, 2018}}</ref>
===Juhl=== Juhl is a mixed-use development project that includes 341 condominium units, some of which are located within a 15-story tower. Units range from {{convert|600|sqft|abbr=on}} to nearly {{convert|2000|sqft|abbr=on}}. Juhl is located at 353 East Bonneville Avenue in downtown Las Vegas.<ref name=Juhl-2017/><ref>{{cite web|title=Juhl official website|url=http://juhllv.com/|accessdate=May 4, 2017}}</ref>
The {{convert|2.4|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}}<ref name=Juhl-topped/> property was initially occupied by four houses. The [[Las Vegas Redevelopment Agency]] solicited proposals from approximately a dozen companies across the United States to develop the land. CityMark Development was chosen in 2004 develop the property.<ref name=Juhl/><ref name=Juhl-topped/> CityMark purchased the property for $5 million,<ref name=Juhl-topped/> and planned to build Juhl, a $167 million mixed-use and condo project. Juhl would include six towers, standing between six and 15 stories, with a total of 341 units. The project would include {{convert|24000|sqft|abbr=on}} of retail space, while parking would be located on the first five floors. The houses on the property were demolished, and by April 2006, $600,000 of underground work and the relocation of utilities had begun on the site. Turner Construction was the general contractor,<ref name=Juhl>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Downtown condo-retail project valued at $167 million under way|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Apr-14-Fri-2006/business/6844356.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 14, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060421170349/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Apr-14-Fri-2006/business/6844356.html|archivedate=April 21, 2006}}</ref> while Martinez-Cuitri was the architect.<ref name=Juhl-60/> Corus Bank provided $106 million for the project.<ref name=High-Tight/>
In August 2006, 600 cubic yards of concrete were delivered by more than 75 trucks for the foundation of the project.<ref name=Apace>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Construction continues apace at Pebble Place|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Aug-14-Mon-2006/business/8954797.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 14, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060821132648/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Aug-14-Mon-2006/business/8954797.html|archivedate=August 21, 2006}}</ref> In December 2006, approximately 60 percent of Juhl's units had been sold through binding purchase agreements. That month, construction crews poured the third and fourth floors of the residential and parking structures for the project. Approximately 115 construction workers were on the site at that time, with the number expected to increase to 200 to 225 within the following 15 to 18 months.<ref name=Juhl-60>{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Hubble |title=Juhl condos 60 percent sold as progress continues: Project will include 340 condominiums, ground-floor shops |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com:80/lvrj_home/2006/Dec-04-Mon-2006/business/11152919.html |work=Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=December 4, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070122010502/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Dec-04-Mon-2006/business/11152919.html |archivedate=January 22, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In July 2007, several businesses were being planned for the new project, including a bar, a coffee shop, and a jewelry store.<ref>{{cite news|title=Juhl promises residents easy stairwell commutes|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/juhl-promises-residents-easy-stairwell-commutes/|accessdate=May 4, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 17, 2007}}</ref> Three cranes were used during construction of the 15-story mid-rise building.<ref name=State-Bird>{{cite news|title=The State Bird of Nevada|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/state-bird-nevada|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 2, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701124233/http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/state-bird-nevada|archivedate=July 1, 2016}}</ref> The 15-story tower was topped off in August 2007, with the first residents expected to move in by May 2008.<ref name=Juhl-topped>{{cite news|title=Juhl high-rise condo tower topped off downtown|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/juhl-high-rise-condo-tower-topped-off-downtown/|accessdate=May 4, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 6, 2007}}</ref> At that time, 70 percent of Juhl's units had been sold.<ref name=Changes-Downtown/> Juhl remained under construction in June 2008, with only 67 percent of its units sold.<ref name=Quiet/> Juhl's planned opening was delayed by more than a year.<ref name=FallFlat/> In August 2011, Juhl still had 307 units left unsold.<ref name=Ramping/>
ST Residential, at a cost of $14 million,<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Chances open up for Las Vegas downtown living space|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/chances-open-up-for-las-vegas-downtown-living-space/|accessdate=May 4, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 13, 2012}}</ref> purchased the project after the failure of Corus in September 2009.<ref name=Juhl-2017/><ref name=Seize/> A bike store, The Town Bike, opened at Juhl in September 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Snel|first=Alan|title=Bike shop owner pedals to the beat of a different drum|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/bike-shop-owner-pedals-to-the-beat-of-a-different-drum/|accessdate=May 4, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 19, 2013}}</ref> In 2013, ST Residential sold Juhl's 306 unsold units to KRE Capital, based in California; Dune Real Estate Partners, based in New York; and Northcap, based in Las Vegas. Juhl's unsold units were turned into rentals. On March 23, 2017, it was announced that Juhl's unsold units would be put on sale in late April 2017, while renewing some rental agreements to keep the building occupied.<ref name=Juhl-2017>{{cite news|last=Segall|first=Eli|title=Owners of Juhl in downtown Las Vegas to begin selling units|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/owners-of-juhl-in-downtown-las-vegas-to-begin-selling-units/|accessdate=May 4, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 23, 2017}}</ref>
===Mandarin Oriental, Las Vegas=== {{Main article|Mandarin Oriental, Las Vegas}} The Mandarin Oriental hotel, located within MGM's mixed-use [[CityCenter]] complex on the Las Vegas Strip, includes 225 condominiums, and was opened in December 2009.
===Newport Lofts=== Newport Lofts is a 23-story, 168-unit tower located at 200 Hoover Street in downtown Las Vegas.<ref name=Newport/> The project was co-developed by Sam Cherry, who also developed [[#Soho Lofts|Soho Lofts]].<ref name=Cherry>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=A Cherry on top|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/oct/18/a-cherry-on-top/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=October 18, 2005}}</ref> In August 2004, Cherry was planning Newport Lofts as a 17-story tower with 131 units, to be built at the northeast corner of Casino Center and Hoover Avenue.<ref name=OnwardUpward/> The project was a joint venture between Cherry and Seegmiller Partners,<ref name=Lofty/> a company based in [[Newport Beach, California]],<ref name=LoftyAims/> with Clark and West Seegmiller as its principals.<ref name=LoftyAims/> The property for the project had been purchased several years earlier by Clark Seegmiller.<ref name=LVS-Jan31-2005/>
In October 2004, the Las Vegas City Council approved Newport Lofts as a 22-story tower with 168 units.<ref name=Lofty/> Groundbreaking was to begin in late May 2005, with completion expected in fall 2006.<ref name=LoftyAims/> Reservations began in January 2005,<ref name=LVS-Jan31-2005/> while groundbreaking began in early July 2005, with Breslin Builders as the project's general contractor. Completion was expected for 2007. That month, the project received $81 million in construction financing from George Smith Partners, based in Irving, California.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Downtown Las Vegas condominium project gains $81 million in construction financing|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jul-30-Sat-2005/business/2705761.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 30, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060721014930/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jul-30-Sat-2005/business/2705761.html|archivedate=July 21, 2006}}</ref> In March 2006, the elevator shaft and center staircase had been built up to the 12th floor, while [[shear wall]]s were up to the eighth floor.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Newport Lofts progress stretching skyward|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/archive/search|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 6, 2006|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Construction was still underway in August 2007, although some new residents had already begun moving into the building by that time. More than 70 percent of the building's units had been sold up to that point.<ref name=Changes-Downtown>{{cite news|last=Goldman|first=Abigail|title=Changes Downtown Coming From On High|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2007/aug/27/changes-downtown-coming-from-on-high/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=August 27, 2007}}</ref> Construction concluded at a cost of $115 million.<ref name=Newport/> Corus Bank helped financed the project for $67.1 million.<ref name=Seize>{{cite news|last=Green|first=Steve|title=Regulators seize Corus Bank, plan sale of Vegas projects|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/sep/12/regulators-seize-corus-bank-plan-sale-vegas-projec/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=September 12, 2009}}</ref> West Seegmiller said Newport Lofts was designed with a [[Southern California]] theme, as its target demographic was California residents who desired to purchase a second home in Las Vegas.<ref name=Newport>{{cite news|title=Newport Lofts: California flair, Las Vegas address|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/newport-lofts-california-flair-las-vegas-address|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 20, 2007}}</ref> In 2007, Newport Lofts won a Mayor's Urban Design Award.<ref>{{cite news|last=Skolnik|first=Sam|title=Vegas Web site garners national award, and trip to Hollywood |url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/sep/03/vegas-web-site-garners-national-award-and-trip-hol/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=September 3, 2008}}</ref>
In January 2008, an auction of 60 units was cancelled after Pyramis Global Advisors {{ndash}} a division of [[Fidelity Investments]] {{ndash}} took over management of the building.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Condo auction won't happen|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/condo-auction-wont-happen|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 15, 2008}}</ref> Condo prices at Newport Lofts were decreased 30 percent later that year.<ref>{{cite news|last=Skolnik|first=Sam|title=Downtown’s biggest booster unbowed|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/aug/15/downtowns-biggest-booster-unbowed/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=August 15, 2008}}</ref> At the end of 2008, artist [[Brett Sperry]] opened the Brett Wesley Gallery inside his penthouse at Newport Lofts.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kristen|title=Investing in the District|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/aug/28/investing-district/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=August 28, 2009|quote=When housing prices dropped, he bought a condo in Newport Lofts. He has been holding exhibits in the penthouse for nine months.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Woodman|first=Xania|title=The Culture Club: In praise of those who put the "art" in "party"|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/mar/05/culture-club/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=March 5, 2009|quote=The Brett Wesley Gallery is temporarily housed in a posh penthouse at Newport Lofts, as swank a place as any for a gallery, not to mention a party.}}</ref> When Corus Bank failed in September 2009, the property was acquired by ST Residential. In April 2011, ST Residential announced that the last of Newport Lofts' units had been sold to buyers.<ref name=SelloutNewport/>
===One Las Vegas=== One Las Vegas is located at the intersection of South Las Vegas Boulevard and Windmill Lane. One Las Vegas was announced in February 2005, as a joint project between Amland Development and B.S.R. Group,<ref name=Feb19/> an international developer based in Israel.<ref name=five-tower/> Chet Nichols, executive vice president for Amland Development, was working with [[Wells Fargo]], [[Wachovia]] and Hypo Real Estate Capital to devise a financial package to help build the project. Grading on the 20-acre property was expected to begin in late February 2005, with construction of the first two towers {{ndash}} standing 20 stories high {{ndash}} expected to begin in July 2005.<ref name=Feb19>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Las Vegas keeps growing up: With building costs climbing, another high-rise condo is in the works|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Feb-19-Sat-2005/business/557851.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=February 19, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050317084133/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Feb-19-Sat-2005/business/557851.html|archivedate=March 17, 2005}}</ref> In February 2005, Amland won the legal rights to use the "One Las Vegas" name, which had also been chosen by Del American for [[#One Las Vegas / Vegas 888|their own condominium project]].<ref name=AmlandOne2>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Rafael building addition on Western High theater|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Feb-14-Mon-2005/business/25839389.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=February 14, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060205091942/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Feb-14-Mon-2005/business/25839389.html|archivedate=February 5, 2006}}</ref><ref name=AmlandOne/> Sales began on April 7, 2005.<ref name="Smith"/>
The first phase, expected to cost $142 million, was under construction in April 2006, with excavation, grading, and underground utility work occurring on the property. J.E. Dunn Construction of Kansas City served as the general contractor. The first phase consisted of two condominium towers, scheduled for completion in December 2007. Approximately 50 percent of the first phase had been presold up to that point. A total of five towers {{ndash}} standing 18 to 21 stories {{ndash}} were ultimately planned for the property, with a final total of 890 condominium units. A 200-room [[boutique hotel]] and a 200-unit condo-hotel {{ndash}} both of which would be operated by the same company {{ndash}} were also planned at that time. By that point, Amland had gained financing from [[Corus Bankshares|Corus Bank]],<ref name=five-tower>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Five-tower project under way: One Las Vegas not after investors, developer says|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Apr-07-Fri-2006/business/6708603.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 7, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060408154115/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Apr-07-Fri-2006/business/6708603.html|archivedate=April 8, 2006}}</ref> which fully financed the project for $142 million.<ref name=OneTops/> Units ranged in price from the $400,000s for an {{convert|850|sqft|abbr=on}} one-bedroom unit to $1.8 million for a {{convert|2850|sqft|abbr=on}} penthouse.<ref name=five-tower/> Units initially started at $275,000 when the project was announced.<ref name=Platinum/>
In October 2006, construction was underway on the two towers, which were expected to have a total of 359 units, with an ultimate total of 960 units when all five towers were completed.<ref name=Platinum>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=South Strip's first luxury tower on the way up: Five towers planned for One Las Vegas|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Oct-30-Mon-2006/business/10424884.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=October 30, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922131001/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Oct-30-Mon-2006/business/10424884.html|archivedate=September 22, 2008}}</ref> The 182-unit first tower was topped off on January 19, 2007, with completion scheduled for late 2007. Construction on the second tower was up to the 16th floor. Approximately 400 construction workers were on the project.<ref name=OneTops>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=One Las Vegas tops tower|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Jan-24-Wed-2007/business/12089484.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 24, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070217000642/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Jan-24-Wed-2007/business/12089484.html|archivedate=February 17, 2007}}</ref> The second tower was topped off in April 2007, and was expected to be completed in early 2008, with the first phase expected to cost $150 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=First building phase finished at Blue Diamond Crossing shopping center|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/first-building-phase-finished-blue-diamond-crossing-shopping-center|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 23, 2007}}</ref>
Delays were attributed to excessive construction activity in Las Vegas, and to the fact that inspections of safety systems did not occur as initially scheduled. Certificates of occupancy were issued for the towers in June 2008. At the time, discussions were underway with two hotel companies for the 220-room boutique hotel.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=One Las Vegas towers get occupancy certificates|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/one-las-vegas-towers-get-occupancy-certificates|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 23, 2008}}</ref> In April 2009, One Las Vegas entered foreclosure because of low sales, and was taken over by Corus Bank, which planned to offer units at a 50 percent discount.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Two more high-rise condominium projects have financial trouble|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/two-more-high-rise-condominium-projects-have-financial-trouble|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 30, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Federal regulators seize Corus Bankshares|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/brief-777|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 12, 2009}}</ref> After Corus Bank failed in September 2009, Starwood Property Trust acquired the project a month later and began renting units because of poor sales; less than 75 of the 359 units had closed on their sales.<ref name=LVS-Jun18-2010/><ref>{{cite news|last=Leonard|first=Devin|title=Barry Sternlicht, the Real Estate Bargain Hunter|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/30/business/30barry.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=May 29, 2010}}</ref> Upgrades totaling $2 million were completed in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robison|first=Jennifer|title=Ogden breaks through with $4 million in sales in four weeks|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/economy/ogden-breaks-through-4-million-sales-four-weeks|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 24, 2015}}</ref>
===One Queensridge Place=== {{Main article|One Queensridge Place}} [[File:Queensridge Place.JPG|right|thumb|One Queensridge Place in 2011]] Originally announced under the name of Versailles in March 1998.<ref name=OnwardUpward/> The project was to consist of three 12-story towers with a total of 84 condominium units, to be constructed on {{convert|14.5|acre|abbr=on}} of land in the Las Vegas community of [[Summerlin, Nevada|Summerlin]]. Construction was to begin in May 1998, with completion scheduled for 14 months later.<ref name=LVS1998>{{cite web|url=http://lasvegassun.com/news/1998/mar/27/buyers-sought-for-million-dollar-condos/|title=Buyers sought for million-dollar condos|date=March 27, 1998|work=Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref name=LVRJ1998>{{cite web|url=http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/1998/Mar-28-Sat-1998/business/7215979.html|title=Upscale condos previewed|last=Caruso|first=Monica|date=March 28, 1998|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19991003032919/http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/1998/Mar-28-Sat-1998/business/7215979.html|archive-date=October 3, 1999}}</ref> In July 2004, a new condominium project was announced for the property under the name of Queensridge Towers,<ref name=July8>{{cite web|url=http://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/jul/08/high-rise-towers-okd-off-rampart/|title=High-rise towers OK’d off Rampart|last=Negron|first=Sito|date=July 8, 2004|work=Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> later changed to One Queensridge Place. Construction began in April 2005,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Nov-07-Mon-2005/business/4148416.html|title=One Queensridge Place project adding investment partner|last=Smith|first=Hubble|date=November 7, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071123040858/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Nov-07-Mon-2005/business/4148416.html|archive-date=November 23, 2007}}</ref> and concluded by September 2007,<ref name=State-Bird/><ref name=Sep15>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/royal-entrance-queensridge|title=Royal entrance at Queensridge|date=September 15, 2007|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> at a cost of $400 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/jan/18/where-art-and-architecture-converge/|title=Where art and architecture converge|last=Hansel|first=Mark|date=January 18, 2008|work=Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> One Queensridge Place consists of two 18-story towers with 219 condominium units, and is located on part of a {{convert|20|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} property near the [[Suncoast Hotel and Casino]] and the [[Tivoli Village]] shopping mall.<ref name=LVRJ-Apr23-2007>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/former-unlv-basketball-player-still-flying-high|title=Former UNLV basketball player still flying high|date=April 23, 2007|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017|quote='''The 20-acre site is approved for two more towers and nearly 400 condo units.'''}}</ref> Two additional towers {{ndash}} standing 14 and 18 stories high {{ndash}} had initially been announced as part of the Queensridge project, and had been approved for the remainder of the 20-acre property.<ref name=LVRJ-Apr23-2007/>
===Palms Place=== {{Further information|Palms Casino Resort#Palms Place}}
===Panorama Towers=== {{Main article|Panorama Towers|The Martin}} [[File:Panorama Towers - East - 2010-03-06.JPG|right|thumb|Panorama Towers (left) and The Martin (right)]] Panorama Towers was announced in September 2003,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://panoramatowers.com/press/vegas-sun-sep8.jpg |title=Condominium Project Planned |work=Las Vegas Sun |date=September 8, 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040620071450/http://panoramatowers.com/press/vegas-sun-sep8.jpg |archivedate=June 20, 2004 }}</ref> and began construction the following year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Third part of high-rise condos approved|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/sep/23/third-part-of-high-rise-condos-approved/|accessdate=February 6, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=September 23, 2004}}</ref> The first tower was opened in December 2006,<ref name=residents>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Most Panorama Tower residents keeping condos|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Mar-05-Mon-2007/business/12888316.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 5, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070315083454/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Mar-05-Mon-2007/business/12888316.html|archivedate=March 15, 2007}}</ref> while a second tower was opened a year later.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rising to New Challenges|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2007/dec/26/rising-to-new-challenges/|accessdate=February 6, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=December 26, 2007|quote=Panorama Towers, a high-rise luxury condo project just west of the Strip, opened its second tower less than three months ago [...]}}</ref> Both towers stand 33 stories high,<ref>{{cite web|title=Panorama Tower I|url=https://www.emporis.com/buildings/196444/panorama-tower-i-las-vegas-nv-usa|publisher=[[Emporis]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Panorama Tower II|url=https://www.emporis.com/buildings/212994/panorama-tower-ii-las-vegas-nv-usa|publisher=Emporis}}</ref> and were built at an estimated cost of $300 million.<ref name=residents/> A third tower, standing 45 stories, was renamed as The Martin in 2011,<ref>{{cite news|title=To lift sales, Panorama North tower renamed The Martin|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/lift-sales-panorama-north-tower-renamed-martin|accessdate=February 7, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 26, 2011}}</ref> and received a $3 million renovation to increase sales.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shine|first=Conor|title=Luxury high-rise sales sent skyward after $3 million remodel injects 'personality'|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2012/mar/14/remodel-injects-personality-increases-sales-luxury/|accessdate=February 7, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=March 14, 2012}}</ref> The complex is located west of Interstate 15 and CityCenter.
===Park Towers=== {{Main|Park Towers (Las Vegas)}} Park Towers is a two-tower, 20-story condominium property with 84 units, located east of the Las Vegas Strip. Park Towers was announced by developer [[Irwin Molasky]] in 1998,<ref name=Swanky/> and began construction the following year, with [[Steve Wynn]] as a co-developer.<ref>{{cite news|last=Levine|first=Phil|title=Luxury condo developer surveys Vegas scene, sees some overbuilding on Strip|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2000/feb/07/luxury-condo-developer-surveys-vegas-scene-sees-so/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=February 7, 2000}}</ref> The project was completed in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last=Leong|first=Grace|title=Suit challenges lien against Park Towers|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2001/aug/09/suit-challenges-lien-against-park-towers/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=August 9, 2001}}</ref>
===Regency Towers=== Regency Towers is located at 3111 Bel Air Drive, at the [[Las Vegas Country Club]] in [[Winchester, Nevada]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=Joan|title=The French Collection|url=http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/1997/Apr-27-Sun-1997/lifestyles/5252008.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 27, 1997|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970720015756/http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/1997/Apr-27-Sun-1997/lifestyles/5252008.html|archivedate=July 20, 1997}}</ref> Regency Towers was built in 1974, and was the first high-rise condominium property to open in the Las Vegas Valley,<ref name=bide/> standing 28 stories<ref name=MethExplode/> with 226 units.<ref name=LVS-Apr8-1999/> Only eight of the units sold after opening, before the property went into foreclosure. Irwin Molasky, who was among the eight buyers, later purchased the entire structure and renovated it before ultimately selling the remaining units.<ref name=LVS-Apr8-1999/> Regency Towers was designed by Las Vegas architect Homer A. Rissman, who also lived at the property for years.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Manning|first1=Mary|last2=Koch|first2=Ed|title=Rissman, architect of Strip hotels, dies of cancer at 74|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2001/oct/04/rissman-architect-of-strip-hotels-dies-of-cancer-a/|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=October 4, 2001}}</ref> In March 2001, approximately 80 residents were evacuated after the explosion of a [[meth lab]] operated by a resident inside one of the condominiums.<ref name=MethExplode>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2001/mar/20/meth-lab-explodes-regency-towers-evacuated/|title= Meth lab explodes; Regency Towers evacuated|last1= Paul|first1= Keith|last2=Koch|first2=Ed|date= March 20, 2001|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 21, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Oliver|first=Ryan|title=Woman arrested in meth lab fire at luxury condo|url=http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/2001/Mar-21-Wed-2001/news/15693759.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 21, 2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021108044529/http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/2001/Mar-21-Wed-2001/news/15693759.html|archivedate=November 8, 2002}}</ref> In March 2007, six weeks of filming began at Regency Towers for the second season of the television series ''[[HGTV Star|HGTV Design Star]]''. The season was shot inside the penthouse formerly owned by Molasky.<ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Extreme penthouse set for makeover|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Mar-19-Mon-2007/news/13260397.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 19, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070322163209/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Mar-19-Mon-2007/news/13260397.html|archivedate=March 22, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Cling|first=Carol|title=Bright Ideas|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/life/bright-ideas|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 29, 2007}}</ref>
Notable tenants at Regency Towers have included [[George Carlin]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Carlin preferred dog's company|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/norm-clarke/carlin-preferred-dogs-company|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 25, 2008}}</ref> [[Don Miguel Ruiz]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Whitely|first=Joan|title=A New Start: Rolling with the Punches|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Oct-21-Thu-2004/living/24821682.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=October 21, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041030054702/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Oct-21-Thu-2004/living/24821682.html|archivedate=October 30, 2004}}</ref> [[Hank Greenspun]] and his wife,<ref>{{cite news|last=Hopkins|first=A.D.|title=H.M. 'Hank' Greenspun|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/hm-hank-greenspun|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 12, 1999}}</ref> [[Shaun King (American football)|Shaun King]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=LaBeouf's star shining brightly|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Mar-13-Tue-2007/news/13142054.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 13, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070315183202/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Mar-13-Tue-2007/news/13142054.html|archivedate=March 15, 2007}}</ref> musician Larry Hart,<ref>{{cite news|last=Weatherford|first=Mike|title=The almost-famous life of Larry Hart|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/mike-weatherford/the-almost-famous-life-larry-hart|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 24, 2015}}</ref> [[Norm Clarke]],<ref name=JacksonPenthouse>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Jackson sneaks into penthouse|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2003/Nov-23-Sun-2003/news/22652139.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=November 23, 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040818094950/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2003/Nov-23-Sun-2003/news/22652139.html|archivedate=August 18, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Branson thinking big for airline|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-29-Fri-2005/news/26406093.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 29, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051127105546/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-29-Fri-2005/news/26406093.html|archivedate=November 27, 2005}}</ref> casino executive Burton Cohen,<ref name=MethExplode/><ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Burton Cohen: A legend and genuine to the core|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/norm-clarke/burton-cohen-legend-and-genuine-core|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 9, 2014}}</ref> Russian-art collector Dr. Rupert Perrin,<ref name=MethExplode/> [[Ted Binion|Sandra Murphy]],<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Peter|title=Jury to hear about Tabish plot|url=http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/2000/Mar-03-Fri-2000/news/13089831.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 3, 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021004220020/http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/2000/Mar-03-Fri-2000/news/13089831.html|archivedate=October 4, 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Peter|title=Murphy booked yet again|url=http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/2000/Mar-17-Fri-2000/news/13188527.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 17, 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021001074932/http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/2000/Mar-17-Fri-2000/news/13188527.html|archivedate=October 1, 2002}}</ref> and [[Anthony Spilotro]].<ref name=Dangerfield/><ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Book tells history of Las Vegas Country Club|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/norm-clarke/book-tells-history-las-vegas-country-club|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 3, 2011}}</ref> [[Moe Dalitz]] owned a penthouse unit until his death there in 1989;<ref name=Dangerfield/><ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Sarah Todora puts music, troubles in past|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/norm-clarke/sarah-todora-puts-music-troubles-past|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 30, 2015}}</ref> his unit, which included his furniture and books, was for sale in 2002 at a cost of $1.2 million. Also for sale at that time was [[Rodney Dangerfield]]'s {{convert|1856|sqft|abbr=on}} unit, at a cost of $275,000.<ref name=Dangerfield>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Dangerfield's condo getting same respect as famed comic|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2002/Oct-30-Wed-2002/news/19939123.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=October 30, 2002|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021220023325/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2002/Oct-30-Wed-2002/news/19939123.html|archivedate=December 20, 2002}}</ref> Actress [[Debbie Reynolds]], who purchased a {{convert|1856|sqft|abbr=on}} condominium unit on the 12th floor in 1974, put her unit up for sale in 2011, at a cost of $269,900.<ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=Reynolds' longtime condo on market|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/norm-clarke/reynolds-longtime-condo-market|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 26, 2011}}</ref> [[La Toya Jackson]] owned a unit from 1996 until 2009, when it was foreclosed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=LaToya Jackson's condo in default|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/norm-clarke/latoya-jacksons-condo-default|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 10, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Clarke|first=Norm|title=A dual celebration for Guy Laliberte |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-28-Wed-2006/news/8205417.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 28, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930225008/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-28-Wed-2006/news/8205417.html|archivedate=September 30, 2007}}</ref>
===Sky Las Vegas=== {{Main article|Sky Las Vegas}} Sky Las Vegas is a 45-story tower with 409 condominium units that is located on the Las Vegas Strip.<ref name=SkyEm/><ref>{{cite news|last=Robison|first=Jennifer|title=Strip drugstore sale one of priciest CVS deals ever|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/business-press/strip-drugstore-sale-one-priciest-cvs-deals-ever|accessdate=March 29, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 14, 2014}}</ref> Sky Las Vegas was announced in July 2004,<ref>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Condo tower in works for north Strip|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/jul/13/condo-tower-in-works-for-north-strip/|accessdate=March 29, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=July 13, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Project adds to vertical reality: Sky Las Vegas is latest entry in high-rise condo building boom|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jul-23-Fri-2004/business/24356555.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 23, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041123091353/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jul-23-Fri-2004/business/24356555.html|archivedate=November 23, 2004}}</ref> and was opened in May 2007,<ref name=PointsDown/> becoming the first high-rise condominium project to be completed on the Las Vegas Strip.<ref name=GrowSlow/>
===Soho Lofts=== Soho Lofts, named after the [[SoHo, Manhattan|Manhattan neighborhood of SoHo]],<ref name=DevelopersDowntown/> is a 16-story condominium tower with 112 units,<ref name=Feldberg/> located within the city's [[18b The Las Vegas Arts District|arts district]]<ref name=Gallery/> at 900 South Las Vegas Boulevard in downtown Las Vegas.<ref name=Feldberg>{{cite news|last=Feldberg|first=Sarah|title=Finding a home with urban sophistication|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2012/may/09/finding-home-urban-sophistication/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=May 9, 2012}}</ref> The project was developed by Sam Cherry, who also developed [[#Newport Lofts|Newport Lofts]].<ref name=Cherry/> Cherry and his father-in-law,<ref name=UrbanSensibility>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Urban sensibility inspires developer to put high-rise condos downtown|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Nov-27-Mon-2006/business/10767217.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=November 27, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310074304/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Nov-27-Mon-2006/business/10767217.html|archivedate=March 10, 2007}}</ref> Harris Rittoff, were planning Soho Lofts in December 2003. The project was to be built at a cost of $40 million to $50 million, on {{convert|0.69|acre|abbr=on}} of vacant property at the southwest corner of South Las Vegas Boulevard and Hoover Avenue. Soho Lofts was the first high-rise condominium project to be announced for the downtown area. Groundbreaking was scheduled for May 2004.<ref name=DevelopersDowntown/> The project was to include {{convert|4000|sqft|abbr=on}} of ground-level retail space.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Mojave Road site to become production center for TV, film|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2003/Dec-29-Mon-2003/business/22872043.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 29, 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041029124221/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2003/Dec-29-Mon-2003/business/22872043.html|archivedate=October 29, 2004}}</ref> The property was purchased in January 2004, at a cost of $1.2 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shubinski|first=Jennifer|title=Condo popularity growing|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/feb/05/condo-popularity-growing/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=February 5, 2004}}</ref>
The project's general contractor was Breslin Builders.<ref name=UrbanSensibility/> Digging for the building's support columns began in July 2004. Construction was expected to cost $60 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=SoHo Lofts developer opens model|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Sep-20-Mon-2004/business/24789892.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 20, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041217053019/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Sep-20-Mon-2004/business/24789892.html|archivedate=December 17, 2004}}</ref> Crews were preparing to begin the structure's foundation work in October 2004.<ref name=Lofty>{{cite news|last=Squires|first=Michael|title=Lofty aspirations taking shape|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Oct-07-Thu-2004/news/24935855.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=October 7, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041124152955/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Oct-07-Thu-2004/news/24935855.html|archivedate=November 24, 2004}}</ref> Occupancy was initially expected for early December 2005.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=Expect growing pains, celebrations in 2005|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/dec/29/expect-growing-pains-celebrations-in-2005/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=December 29, 2004}}</ref> Occupancy was later expected for February 2006,<ref>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=Changes on tap for LV in 2006|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2006/jan/01/changes-on-tap-for-lv-in-2006/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=January 1, 2006}}</ref> although construction was ongoing in April 2006.<ref name=Juhl/>
In May 2006, an automobile dealership {{ndash}} for [[Lamborghini]]s, [[Ferrari]]s, and [[Rolls-Royce Motor Cars|Rolls-Royce]]s {{ndash}} was being planned for the building's ground floor, while residents were expected to begin occupying the building later that month.<ref>{{cite news|last=McGrath Schwartz|first=David|title=High-end autos in high-rise: Exotic-car retailer putting showroom in condo project|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/May-01-Mon-2006/news/7048589.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 1, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518114848/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/May-01-Mon-2006/news/7048589.html|archivedate=May 18, 2006}}</ref> In December 2007, a lease was signed for the Dust Contemporary Fine Art gallery to occupy a {{convert|1300|sqft|abbr=on}} space inside Soho Lofts.<ref name=Gallery>{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kristen|title=Another gallery makes its move|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2007/dec/20/another-gallery-makes-its-move/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=December 20, 2007}}</ref> The gallery opened two months later.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kristen|title=Comings and goings in the Las Vegas art scene|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/feb/14/comings-and-goings-las-vegas-art-scene/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=February 14, 2008}}</ref> The Globe Salon was the first business to occupy Soho Lofts' commercial space, beginning in July 2008; the rest of the space remained vacant because of the poor economy.<ref name=Resnicks/>
By 2009, the Naomi Arin Contemporary Art gallery was operating inside Soho Lofts.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kristen|title=Economy puts hold on home for art downtown|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/feb/10/economy-puts-hold-home-art-downtown/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=February 10, 2009}}</ref> In January 2011, a small grocery store, Resnicks Grocery, opened inside a {{convert|1400|sqft|abbr=on}} space inside Soho Lofts that was previously occupied by an art gallery.<ref name=Resnicks>{{cite news|last=Takahashi|first=Paul|title=For downtown Las Vegas, a grocery store with an attitude|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2011/jan/17/downtown-grocery-store-attitude/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=January 17, 2011}}</ref> A lounge, known as The Lady Silvia, opened inside Soho Lofts in July 2011.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kristen|title=New Downtown lounge Lady Silvia brings Old World charm|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2011/jun/29/new-downtown-lounge-lady-silvia-brings-old-world-c/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The Amanda Harris Gallery opened inside Soho Lofts in January 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Kristen|title=Amanda Harris Gallery opens Downtown with a Dahl-Berg bang|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2012/jun/27/amanda-harris-gallery-opens-downtown-dahl-berg-ban/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 27, 2012}}</ref> The Contemporary Arts Center later operated from within one of Soho Loft's ground-level spaces.<ref>{{cite news|last=Carter|first=Geoff|title=What's happening with the Contemporary Arts Center?|url=https://lasvegasweekly.com/intersection/2017/jan/18/whats-happening-contemporary-arts-center/|accessdate=March 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Weekly|date=January 18, 2017}}</ref>
===The Ogden=== {{Main article|The Ogden}} The Ogden was initially opened as the Streamline Tower,<ref name=Upgrades>{{cite news|last=Snel|first=Alan|title=Ogden getting $2 million in upgrades|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/ogden-getting-2-million-upgrades-photos|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 19, 2015}}</ref> built on the {{convert|1|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} property of the demolished Golden Inn motel in downtown Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Work on Streamline Tower condominium starting soon|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-03-Mon-2005/business/25569094.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 3, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050104190344/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-03-Mon-2005/business/25569094.html|archivedate=January 4, 2005}}</ref> Streamline Tower opened in May 2008, with 275 condominium units in a 21-story tower, although sales suffered as a result of the weak local and national economy.<ref name=Quiet>{{cite news|last=Skolnik|first=Sam|title=Quiet on the northern front: Downtown condo tower mostly empty as revitalization efforts limp along|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/jun/11/quiet-northern-front/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 11, 2008}}</ref> The units were converted into apartments in 2010,<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Reilly|first=Tim|title=Streamline Tower switches from condominiums to apartments|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/streamline-tower-switches-condominiums-apartments|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=November 27, 2010}}</ref> and the property was renamed as The Ogden a year later. In 2014, The Ogden was converted back into condominiums.<ref name=Upgrades/>
===The Platinum=== {{Main|The Platinum}} The Platinum is a 17-story,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Platinum, Las Vegas|url=https://www.emporis.com/buildings/192360/the-platinum-las-vegas-nv-usa|publisher=[[Emporis]]|accessdate=June 28, 2017}}</ref> 255-unit condo hotel built on {{convert|1.7|acre|abbr=on}} of land, previously occupied by a motel and located east of the Las Vegas Strip.<ref>{{cite news|last=Benston|first=Liz|title=Living the life off the Strip |url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2007/jun/14/living-the-life-off-the-strip/|accessdate=June 28, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 14, 2007}}</ref> The project was developed by Platinum Condominium Development, LLC, a joint venture of Diversified Real Estate Concepts, Inc. and [[Marcus Corporation|Marcus Hotels and Resorts]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Marcus Hotels and Resorts/Diversified Real Estate Concepts Form Joint Venture to Build Luxury Condominium Hotel in Las Vegas|url=http://investors.marcuscorp.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=99966&p=irol-newsArticle_pf&ID=488515|accessdate=June 28, 2017|publisher=[[Marcus Corporation]]|date=January 27, 2004}}</ref> Construction began in 2005,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-18-Mon-2005/business/1156061.html|title= Foundation work complete for 16-story condominium|last= Smith|first= Hubble|date= April 18, 2005|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20051213061051/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Apr-18-Mon-2005/business/1156061.html|archive-date= December 13, 2005}}</ref> and the project opened in October 2006.<ref name=Platinum/>
===The Signature at MGM Grand=== {{Main article|The Signature at MGM Grand}} [[File:The Signature at MGM Grand, Las Vegas.jpg|thumb|right|The Signature in 2015]] The Signature is a condo hotel located near the [[MGM Grand Las Vegas]] resort. The project was jointly developed by MGM Mirage and Turnberry Associates, and opened in 2006, on the former land of [[MGM Grand Adventures Theme Park]].
===Trump International=== {{Main article|Trump International Hotel Las Vegas}} [[File:EM TRUMP TOWER (2844216335).jpg|thumb|right|Trump International in 2008]] In April 2002, businessmen [[Phil Ruffin]] and [[Donald Trump]] announced plans to build Trump Tower Las Vegas, a $300 million, 60-story condominium tower with 300 units. Construction had been expected to begin within seven months.<ref>{{cite news|last= Robison|first= Jennifer|url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2002/apr/23/trump-ruffin-in-lv-luxury-condo-deal/|title= Trump, Ruffin in LV luxury condo deal|date= April 23, 2002|newspaper= [[Las Vegas Sun]]|accessdate= March 16, 2017}}</ref> Groundbreaking took place in July 2005,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jul-12-Tue-2005/business/2469393.html|title=With project's start, Trump's time has come|last=Stutz|first=Howard|date=July 12, 2005|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051118155355/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jul-12-Tue-2005/business/2469393.html|archive-date=November 18, 2005}}</ref> after the project had been revised to include a hotel.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Chris|title=Trump unveils Strip tower plan|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jul-30-Fri-2004/news/24425798.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 30, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050104090649/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jul-30-Fri-2004/news/24425798.html|archivedate=January 4, 2005}}</ref> The 64-floor tower was constructed behind the Las Vegas Strip's [[New Frontier Hotel and Casino]], on {{convert|3|acre|abbr=on}} of property that had been used as part of the New Frontier's rear parking lot.<ref name= july13>{{cite news|last= Benston|first= Liz|url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/jul/13/trump-the-star-of-the-show-in-condo-resort-groundb/|title= Trump the star of the show in condo resort groundbreaking|date= July 13, 2005|newspaper= Las Vegas Sun|accessdate= March 16, 2017}}</ref> The project ultimately cost $500 million,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Oct-15-Sun-2006/business/9667092.html|title=The Next Wave|last=Stutz|first=Howard|date=October 15, 2006|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201164752/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Oct-15-Sun-2006/business/9667092.html|archive-date=December 1, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/site-work-under-way-windmill-lane-plaza|title=Site work under way for Windmill Lane Plaza|date=May 28, 2007|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> and opened in 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://mix941fm.cbslocal.com/2011/07/05/recap-the-good-years-with-mayor-oscar-goodman/trump-international-hotel-tower-las-vegas-opening-ceremony/|title= Trump International Hotel & Tower Las Vegas - Opening Ceremony|publisher= CBS| date= July 5, 2011|accessdate= March 16, 2017}}</ref> with a total of 1,282 condominium units and hotel rooms. A nearly identical second tower had been planned,<ref name=april9>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/tower-pitch-goes-prime-time|title=Tower Pitch Goes Prime Time|date=April 9, 2007|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> but was postponed due to poor economic conditions.<ref>{{cite news|last = Botkin|first= Ben|url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/politics/elections/trump-has-piece-las-vegas|title= Trump has a piece of Las Vegas|date= August 1, 2015|newspaper= Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate= March 16, 2017}}</ref> Construction of the second tower had been expected to begin in late 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/opening-slated-trump-condo-hotel|title=Opening slated for Trump condo-hotel|date=February 5, 2008|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>
===Turnberry Place=== {{Main article|Turnberry Place}} [[File:Turnberry Towers Las Vegas.jpg|thumb|right|Turnberry Place in 2006]] Turnberry Place was announced in June 1998,<ref>{{cite news|title=Massive luxury LV condo project coming|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/1998/jun/30/massive-luxury-lv-condo-project-coming/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 30, 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Plans unveiled for upscale condo tower|url=http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/1998/Jul-01-Wed-1998/business/7772896.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 1, 1998|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000914063509/http://www.lvrj.com/lvrj_home/1998/Jul-01-Wed-1998/business/7772896.html|archivedate=September 14, 2000}}</ref> and consists of four 40-story condominium towers located east of the Las Vegas Strip.
===Turnberry Towers=== {{Main article|Turnberry Towers}} Turnberry Towers is a two-tower property near the Las Vegas Strip. The towers stand 45 stories and contain a total of 636 units.
===Vdara=== {{Main article|Vdara}} Vdara, opened in December 2008, is a condo hotel within CityCenter that includes 1,495 units.
===Veer Towers=== {{Main article|Veer Towers}} Veer Towers, located within CityCenter, consists of twin towers that stand 37 stories high and include 670 condominium units. The towers opened in July 2010.
==On hold==
===St. Regis Residences=== {{Further information|The Palazzo#St. Regis Residences at the Venetian Palazzo, Las Vegas}}
The St. Regis Residences at the Venetian Palazzo, Las Vegas is an unfinished condominium tower located on the Las Vegas Strip, between the [[The Palazzo|Palazzo]] and [[The Venetian Las Vegas|Venetian]] resorts.<ref name=Pact>{{cite news|title=Pact reached on St. Regis Residences|url=https://lasvegassun.com/blogs/elsewhere/2008/sep/04/pact-reached-st-regis-residences/|accessdate=February 21, 2018|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=September 4, 2008}}</ref> Construction began in early 2007,<ref>{{cite news|title=Sands raises condo ante|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/sands-raises-condo-ante/|accessdate=February 21, 2018|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 18, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The St. Regis Residences at the Venetian Palazzo|url=https://www.emporis.com/buildings/318109/the-st-regis-residences-at-the-venetian-palazzo-las-vegas-nv-usa|website=Emporis|accessdate=February 21, 2018}}</ref> and the opening was eventually scheduled for March 2010.<ref name=Pact/> The tower was to stand 50 stories,<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Reiley|first=Tim|title=That's a wrap: Las Vegas Sands finishes condos with giant cloths|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/thats-a-wrap-las-vegas-sands-finishes-condos-with-giant-cloths/|accessdate=February 21, 2018|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 10, 2011}}</ref> with a total of 398 condominium units. The project was expected to cost $600 million,<ref>{{cite news|last=Stutz|first=Howard|title=High-rise goes high-end with Regis brand|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/high-rise-goes-high-end-with-regis-brand/|accessdate=February 21, 2018|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 5, 2008}}</ref> but construction was indefinitely suspended in November 2008 because of the Great Recession.<ref>{{cite news|last=Benston|first=Liz|title=Las Vegas Sands shelves projects: Company seeks $2 billion to stay afloat|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/nov/10/las-vegas-sands-shelves-projects-seeks-2-billion-s/|accessdate=February 21, 2018|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=November 10, 2008}}</ref> In April 2014, the project was no longer expected to be finished as a condominium tower because of uncertainty in the high-end, high-rise residential market. Up to that point, several other options had been considered regarding the building's future use.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stutz|first=Howard|title='Cover-up' is over: Las Vegas Sands moving past 'million-dollar' tarp|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/cover-up-is-over-las-vegas-sands-moving-past-million-dollar-tarp/|accessdate=February 21, 2018|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=April 2, 2014}}</ref>
==Cancelled projects== ===Ambling Development Company project=== In 2004, the Atlanta-based Ambling Development Company held meetings with mayor Oscar Goodman, councilman Lawrence Weekly, and other city officials regarding a condominium project.<ref name=Ambling1/><ref name=LVRJ-Dec22-2004>{{cite news|last=Kalil|first=J.M.|title=Worker misled firm, LV says|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-22-Wed-2004/news/25528150.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 22, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041229180927/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-22-Wed-2004/news/25528150.html|archivedate=December 29, 2004}}</ref> Ambling was planning a complex of three 28-story condominium towers with a total of 840 units, to be built at a cost of $330 million on {{convert|16.8|acre|abbr=on}} at the northwest corner of Alta Drive and South Martin Luther King Boulevard.<ref name=Ambling1>{{cite news|last=Kalil|first=J.M.|title=City Council kills condo project|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-16-Thu-2004/news/25489035.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 16, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041228192457/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-16-Thu-2004/news/25489035.html|archivedate=December 28, 2004}}</ref><ref name=Rejection>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=LV City Council rejection stuns high-rise developer|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/dec/16/lv-city-council-rejection-stuns-high-rise-develope/|accessdate=March 16, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=December 16, 2004}}</ref> The land had previously been occupied by a gas station, which was later burned down during a riot.<ref>{{cite news|title=City wants redevelopment?|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-17-Fri-2004/opinion/25495732.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 17, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041228191007/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-17-Fri-2004/opinion/25495732.html|archivedate=December 28, 2004}}</ref>
Ambling invested $2 million to acquire the land, to open a Las Vegas office, and to perform initial design work. Months later, on December 15, 2004, the City Council voted unanimously to reject Ambling's project because of opposition from nearby residents, who believed that the tall modern-style glass buildings would not go well with the neighborhood's southwestern theme and its 600 single-story houses.<ref name=Ambling1/><ref name=Rejection/><ref>{{cite news|last=Kalil|first=J.M.|title=Condominium Controversy: Residents praise Weekly|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-30-Thu-2004/news/25562756.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 30, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041231040825/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-30-Thu-2004/news/25562756.html|archivedate=December 31, 2004}}</ref> Residents also believed the new project would create traffic problems and overcrowd nearby schools. Weekly criticized city staff members, alleging that they misled Ambling to believe that their project was guaranteed to be approved by the City Council.<ref name=Ambling1/><ref name=LVRJ-Dec22-2004/><ref name=Rejection/><ref>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=Selby says staff enthusiasm may have misled developer|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/dec/22/selby-says-staff-enthusiasm-may-have-misled-develo/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=December 22, 2004}}</ref> The manager of the city's Economic Development division, who had worked with Ambling on their project, resigned from his position two days after the vote.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kalil|first=J.M.|title=City worker in condo flap leaves post|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-23-Thu-2004/news/25534629.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 23, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041228233650/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-23-Thu-2004/news/25534629.html|archivedate=December 28, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=Head of LV economic development resigns|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/dec/23/head-of-lv-economic-development-resigns/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=December 23, 2004}}</ref>
In June 2005, Ambling was unanimously approved by the City Council for a smaller version of its initial project to be constructed on the same property. The new project was to consist of three nine-story buildings and one five-story building, with retail space and a total of 664 condominium units. The project was to be built in phases, with construction planned to begin at the end of 2005, and the first phase being potentially completed in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kulin|first=Dan|title=LV Council OKs condo complex|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/jun/02/lv-council-oks-condo-complex/|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 2, 2005}}</ref> The project was ultimately cancelled due to further opposition from nearby residents. The land was subsequently sold in February 2006.<ref>{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Valerie|title=West Las Vegas among potential stadium sites|work=Las Vegas Business Press|date=May 14, 2007|quote='''The Cox building is across MLK from Costco Wholesalers and diagonal from land owned by Mark Fine. The elder Fine also has 17 acres at the northwest corner of MLK and Alta Drive. Mark Fine acquired his parcel from Atlanta-based Ambling Development Co. for $27.6 million in February 2006. Resident protests had killed Ambling's proposal to build a $350 million condominium project there. […] The area is known for controversy. Not only was the Ambling project quashed by neighborhood opposition more than a year ago. West Las Vegas residents have also fought a contentious battle for a neighborhood supermarket in the area for the past three years.'''}}</ref>
===Aqua Blue=== By December 2004, the newly created high-rise development division of Prudential Americana Group Realtors was planning Aqua Blue, a luxury condominium-hotel project. Aqua Blue was the division's flagship project, with gross sales expected to exceed $550 million.<ref name=LoftyAims>{{cite web |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-18-Sat-2004/business/25502178.html|title= Builders have lofty aims for downtown condos|last= Smith|first= Hubble|date= December 18, 2004|work= Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20041228183325/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-18-Sat-2004/business/25502178.html|archive-date= December 28, 2004}}</ref> The project was approved that year, and was to be constructed east of the Las Vegas Strip near the intersection of Flamingo Road and Koval Lane,<ref name=LVS-Jan6-2005>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/jan/06/jordan-to-open-fitness-center-restaurants-in-lv/|title= Jordan to open fitness center, restaurants in LV|date= January 6, 2005|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> on {{convert|3.6|acre|abbr=on}} of property<ref name=LVRJ-Jun30-2005/> that was occupied at the time by a [[Super 8 Motels|Super 8]] motel, located adjacent to the [[Ellis Island Casino & Brewery]]. The motel was to be demolished to make room for Aqua Blue, while Ellis Island would continue operations but would receive an exterior renovation to match the appearance of the new project.<ref name=LVS-Jan17-2005/>
Aqua Blue would have included a {{convert|12000|sqft|abbr=on}} casino that would be operated by Gary Ellis, who owned the Ellis Island. Ellis decided to become involved in the Aqua Blue after meeting with the project's developer, Michael Peterson, who had developed and owned condominiums and restaurants in Wisconsin and Chicago.<ref name=LVS-Jan17-2005/> Aqua Blue was to stand 46 stories,<ref name=LVRJ-Jun30-2005/> and would have included 825 units,<ref name=LVS-Jul1-2005/> priced between $399,000 and $1,125,000.<ref name=LVS-Jan17-2005/> The project's expected cost was $600 million.<ref name=LVRJ-Jun30-2005/> Construction was expected to begin in fall 2005, and its opening was expected to occur by fall 2007.<ref name=LVS-Jan17-2005/>
In January 2005, retired basketball player [[Michael Jordan]] became involved in Aqua Blue.<ref name=LVS-Jan6-2005/><ref name=LVS-Jan17-2005/> Jordan was to open two restaurants at Aqua Blue: Michael Jordon's Steak House and Michael Jordon's 23 Sportcafe.<ref name=LVS-Jan17-2005>{{cite web |url= http://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/jan/17/high-rise-developer-brings-strengths-to-vegas/|title= High-rise developer brings strengths to Vegas|last= Benston|first= Liz|date= January 17, 2005|work= Las Vegas Sun|access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref> Jordan would also open the {{convert|65000|sqft|abbr=on}} Michael Jordan Athletic Center inside the new building.<ref name=LVS-Jan6-2005/><ref name=LVS-Jan17-2005/> In June 2005, Peterson began considering offers for the property.
